To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Metals heavier than what element are formed in supernovae?
Options: A. Copper, B. Silver, C. Nickel, D. Gold
Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What percentage of energy from a supernova explosion is expelled as neutrinos?
Options: A. 1, B. 90, C. 99, D. 10
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: How often does a supernova occur in the observable universe? Options: A. Every 25 to 50 years, B. Every second or so, C. Every 100 years, D. Every 1000 years Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the primary challenge in observing a supernova from its first violent moments? Options: A. The explosion is too faint to detect, B. The odds of having a telescope focused on the right star at the right time are low, C. Supernovae only occur in distant galaxies, D. Supernovae only occur at night Correct Option: B
Question 3: What type of particle typically reaches Earth before photons from a supernova? Options: A. Neutrons, B. Protons, C. Neutrinos, D. Electrons Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is the main difference between a Type 1 and Type 2 supernova? Options: A. The amount of energy released, B. The type of star that explodes, C. The cause of the explosion (accumulation of matter vs. running out of nuclear fuel), D. The location of the supernova Correct Option: C
Question 5: What percentage of the energy released in a Type 2 supernova consists of photons? Options: A. 1%, B. 10%, C. 50%, D. 99% Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why do neutrinos from a supernova reach Earth before photons? Options: A. Neutrinos travel faster than photons, B. Neutrinos take a more direct route through the star, C. Neutrinos are emitted before photons, D. Neutrinos are more massive than photons Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of the SNEWS project? Options: A. To detect supernovae in distant galaxies, B. To study the properties of neutrinos, C. To provide an early warning system for supernovae, D. To observe the visible light from supernovae Correct Option: C
Question 8: How do amateur astronomers and scientists contribute to the SNEWS project? Options: A. By detecting neutrinos with their own equipment, B. By scanning the skies and sharing information to quickly identify the new galactic supernova, C. By analyzing data from the neutrino detectors, D. By predicting when the next supernova will occur Correct Option: B
Question 9: What was notable about the supernova that occurred in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula? Options: A. It was the brightest supernova ever observed, B. It was the closest supernova to Earth, C. Its neutrinos reached Earth about three hours ahead of the visible light, D. It was the first supernova detected by the SNEWS project Correct Option: C
Question 10: What is a potential benefit of the SNEWS project for astronomers and scientists? Options: A. It will allow them to predict when the next supernova will occur, B. It will give them the opportunity to be among the first to witness a supernova from its first violent moments, C. It will provide them with more accurate data on the properties of neutrinos, D. It will enable them to detect supernovae in distant galaxies Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

Although the question wording is not identical, the intent and content of Question 5 align with the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the percentage of energy from a supernova explosion that is expelled as neutrinos, while Question 5 asks about the percentage of energy released in a Type 2 supernova that consists of photons. 

Given that the ground truth MCQ states that 99% of the energy radiates out as neutrinos and Question 5 states that 1% of the energy consists of photons, it can be inferred that the remaining 99% is neutrinos, making Question 5 the most similar generated MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: A supernova is defined as _____.
Options: A. Meteor, B. Satellite crash, C. Planet explosion, D. Death of a star
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 8, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. **Transcript**:
Just now, somewhere in the universe,
a star exploded. There goes another one. In fact, a supernova occurs every second
or so in the observable universe, and there is one on average
every 25 to 50 years in a galaxy the size 
and age of the Milky Way. Yet we've never actually been able
to watch one happen from its first violent moments. Of course, how would we? There are hundreds of billions
of stars close enough that we could watch 
the supernova explosion break through the surface of the star. But we'd have to have our best telescopes
focused on the right one at precisely the right time
to get meaningful data. Suffice it to say, the odds of that
happening are astronomically low. But what if we could anticipate 
a supernova before its light reached us? That may seem impossible. After all, nothing travels faster
than the speed of light, right? As far as we know, yes. But in a race, fast doesn't matter
if you take a detour while someone else beelines it
for the finish line. For exactly that reason, photons don't win 
the supernova race to Earth. Neutrinos do. Here's why. There are two types of supernova. Type 1 is when a star accumulates
so much matter from a neighboring star, that a runaway nuclear reaction ignites
and causes it to explode. In type 2, the star runs out 
of nuclear fuel, so the gravitational forces pulling in overwhelm the quantum mechanical 
forces pushing out, and the stellar core collapses under
its own weight in a hundredth of a second. While the outer reaches of the star
are unaffected by the collapsed core, the inner edges accelerate 
through the void, smash into the core,
and rebound to launch the explosion. In both of these scenarios, the star expels an unparalleled
amount of energy, as well as a great deal of matter. In fact, all atoms heavier than nickel,
including elements like gold and silver, only form in supernova reactions. In type 2 supernovae, about 1% of the energy 
consists of photons, which we know of as light, while 99% radiates out as neutrinos, the elementary particles that are known
for rarely interacting with anything. Starting from the center of the star, the exploding matter takes 
tens of minutes, or even hours, or in rare cases, several days, to reach
and break through the surface of the star. However, the neutrinos, 
thanks to their non-interactivity, take a much more direct route. By the time there is any visible change
in the star's suface, the neutrinos typically have a several
hour head start over the photons. That's why astronomers and physicists have been able to set up a project
called SNEWS, the Supernova Early Warning System. When detectors around the world
pick up bursts of neutrinos, they send messages 
to a central computer in New York. If multiple detectors receive 
similar signals within ten seconds, SNEWS will trigger an alert warning
that a supernova is imminent. Aided by some distance and direction
information from the neutrino detectors, the amateur astronomers 
and scientists alike will scan the skies and share information to quickly identify 
the new galactic supernova and turn the world's major 
telescopes in that direction. The last supernova that sent detectable
neutrinos to Earth was in 1987 on the edge of the Tarantula Nebula in the large Magellanic Cloud,
a nearby galaxy. Its neutrinos reached Earth about
three hours ahead of the visible light. We're due for another one any day now,
and when that happens, SNEWS should give you the opportunity
to be among the first to witness something that no human has ever seen before.

Options: A. 1987, B. 1999, C. 1978, D. 1969

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The three indices of the fraud triangle are pressure, opportunity and _____.
Options: A. Critical thinking, B. Rationalization, C. Justification, D. Validation
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to the transcript, what was the estimated total amount lost by organizations worldwide to fraud in 2013? Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are the three conditions that make fraud likely, according to the fraud triangle model developed by criminologist Donald Cressey? Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and skill, B. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, C. Motivation, means, and chance, D. Greed, need, and circumstance Correct Option: B
Question 3: An employee is struggling to pay their personal debt and has access to the company's internal data. What might be the likely outcome, according to the transcript? Options: A. The employee will be more productive to earn a promotion, B. The employee will be more likely to commit fraud, C. The employee will be more transparent about their financial struggles, D. The employee will be more diligent in their work to avoid being fired Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a common way for individuals to rationalize committing fraud, according to the transcript? Options: A. They feel entitled to the money because they are underpaid and overworked, B. They believe the company owes them a favor, C. They think the company will never notice, D. They believe it's a victimless crime Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the case of Rita Crundwell, the former City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois? Options: A. She was a victim of embezzlement, B. She embezzled over 53 million dollars to fund her horse breeding business, C. She was a whistleblower who exposed a large-scale embezzlement scheme, D. She was a successful businesswoman who was wrongly accused of embezzlement Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the impact of fraud on individuals and communities, according to the transcript? Options: A. It is a victimless crime that only affects corporations, B. It only affects the perpetrator and their immediate family, C. It can have devastating effects on employees, customers, and taxpayers, D. It has no significant impact on the economy or society Correct Option: C
Question 7: How do individuals often justify small-scale fraudulent behavior, such as fudging time sheets or expense reports? Options: A. They believe it's a way to get back at the company for underpaying them, B. They think it's a victimless crime that won't hurt anyone, C. They rationalize it as a necessary evil to make ends meet, D. They believe it's a legitimate way to earn extra income Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the case of Parmalat, the Italian dairy food giant? Options: A. It was a successful company that was acquired by a competitor, B. It went bankrupt after fabricating a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsifying financial statements, C. It was a victim of a large-scale embezzlement scheme, D. It was a company that successfully recovered from a financial crisis Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the role of rationalization in the fraud triangle model? Options: A. It is the primary motivator for individuals to commit fraud, B. It is the means by which individuals justify their fraudulent behavior to themselves, C. It is the opportunity that allows individuals to commit fraud, D. It is the pressure that drives individuals to commit fraud Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the overall message of the transcript regarding fraud? Options: A. It is a rare occurrence that only affects a few individuals, B. It is a victimless crime that has no significant impact on society, C. It is a widespread problem that can have devastating effects on individuals and communities, D. It is a necessary evil that is required for business success Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 2: What are the three conditions that make fraud likely, according to the fraud triangle model developed by criminologist Donald Cressey?**

Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and skill, B. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, C. Motivation, means, and chance, D. Greed, need, and circumstance

Correct Option: B

This question directly addresses the components of the fraud triangle, matching the intent and content of the ground truth MCQ. The correct option, "Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization," aligns with the correct answer in the ground truth MCQ.

**Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 2**

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Fraud is a $_____ problem.
Options: A. 2.5 billion, B. 3.7 trillion, C. 100 billion, D. 10 trillion
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: According to the transcript, what was the estimated total amount lost by organizations worldwide to fraud in 2013? Options: A. 1 trillion dollars, B. 3.7 trillion dollars, C. 5 trillion dollars, D. 10 trillion dollars Correct Option: B
Question 2: What are the three conditions that make fraud likely, according to the fraud triangle model developed by criminologist Donald Cressey? Options: A. Pressure, opportunity, and skill, B. Pressure, opportunity, and rationalization, C. Motivation, means, and chance, D. Greed, need, and circumstance Correct Option: B
Question 3: An employee is struggling to pay their personal debt and has access to the company's internal data. What might be the likely outcome, according to the transcript? Options: A. The employee will be more productive to earn a promotion, B. The employee will be more likely to commit fraud, C. The employee will be more transparent about their financial struggles, D. The employee will be more diligent in their work to avoid being fired Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is a common way for individuals to rationalize committing fraud, according to the transcript? Options: A. They feel entitled to the money because they are underpaid and overworked, B. They believe the company owes them a favor, C. They think the company will never notice, D. They believe it's a victimless crime Correct Option: A
Question 5: What was the case of Rita Crundwell, the former City Comptroller for Dixon, Illinois? Options: A. She was a victim of embezzlement, B. She embezzled over 53 million dollars to fund her horse breeding business, C. She was a whistleblower who exposed a large-scale embezzlement scheme, D. She was a successful businesswoman who was wrongly accused of embezzlement Correct Option: B
Question 6: What is the impact of fraud on individuals and communities, according to the transcript? Options: A. It is a victimless crime that only affects corporations, B. It only affects the perpetrator and their immediate family, C. It can have devastating effects on employees, customers, and taxpayers, D. It has no significant impact on the economy or society Correct Option: C
Question 7: How do individuals often justify small-scale fraudulent behavior, such as fudging time sheets or expense reports? Options: A. They believe it's a way to get back at the company for underpaying them, B. They think it's a victimless crime that won't hurt anyone, C. They rationalize it as a necessary evil to make ends meet, D. They believe it's a legitimate way to earn extra income Correct Option: B
Question 8: What was the case of Parmalat, the Italian dairy food giant? Options: A. It was a successful company that was acquired by a competitor, B. It went bankrupt after fabricating a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsifying financial statements, C. It was a victim of a large-scale embezzlement scheme, D. It was a company that successfully recovered from a financial crisis Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the role of rationalization in the fraud triangle model? Options: A. It is the primary motivator for individuals to commit fraud, B. It is the means by which individuals justify their fraudulent behavior to themselves, C. It is the opportunity that allows individuals to commit fraud, D. It is the pressure that drives individuals to commit fraud Correct Option: B
Question 10: What is the overall message of the transcript regarding fraud? Options: A. It is a rare occurrence that only affects a few individuals, B. It is a victimless crime that has no significant impact on society, C. It is a widespread problem that can have devastating effects on individuals and communities, D. It is a necessary evil that is required for business success Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent (asking about the estimated total amount lost to fraud), options (providing different dollar amounts), and content (specifically referencing the estimated total amount lost by organizations worldwide to fraud in 2013). 

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 1.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 9, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
If you ask people whether 
they think stealing is wrong, most of them would answer, "Yes." And yet, in 2013, organizations
all over the world lost an estimated total
of 3.7 trillion dollars to fraud, which includes crimes like embezzlement, pyramid schemes, and false insurance claims. This wasn't just the work
of a few bad apples. The truth is that many people
are susceptible not only to the temptation 
to commit fraud but to convincing themselves
that they've done nothing wrong. So why does fraud happen? While individual motivations 
may differ from case to case, the fraud triangle, a model developed
by criminologist Donald Cressey, shows three conditions 
that make fraud likely: pressure, opportunity,
and rationalization. Pressure is often what motivates someone
to engage in fraud to begin with. It could be a personal debt, an addiction, an earnings quota, a sudden job loss, or an illness in the family. As for opportunity, many people
in both public and private sectors have access to tools that enable them
to commit and conceal fraud: corporate credit cards, internal company data, or control over the budget. The combination of pressure and being exposed to such opportunities
on a daily basis can create a strong temptation. But even with these two elements, most fraud still requires rationalization. Many fraudsters are first time offenders, so in order to commit an act
most would regard as wrong, they need to justify it to themselves. Some feel entitled to the money
because they are underpaid and overworked and others believe 
their fraud is victimless, perhaps even planning to return
the money once their crisis is resolved. Some of the most common types of fraud don't even register as such
to the perpetrator. Examples include employees
fudging time sheets or expense reports, taxpayers failing to report cash earnings, or service providers overbilling
insurance companies. Though these may seem small, and can sometimes
only involve hundreds of dollars, they all contribute to the big picture. And then there's fraud on a massive scale. In 2003, Italian dairy food giant 
Parmalat went bankrupt after it was found to have fabricated
a 4 billion dollar bank account and falsified financial statements to hide the fact that its subsidiaries
had been losing money. Because it was family controlled, corporate governance 
and regulator supervision were difficult, and the company likely hoped 
that the losses could be recouped before anyone found out. And it's not just corporate greed. Governments and non-profits
are also susceptible to fraud. During her time as City Comptroller
for Dixon, Illinois, Rita Crundwell embezzled 
over 53 million dollars. Rita was one of the country's leading 
quarter horse breeders and winner of 52 world championships. But the cost of maintaining the herd
ran to 200,000 dollars per month. Because her position gave her complete
control over city finances, she was easily able to divert money to an account she used 
for private expenses, and the scheme went 
unnoticed for 20 years. It is believed that Crundwell
felt entitled to a lavish lifestyle based on her position, and the notoriety 
her winnings brought to the city. It's tempting to think of fraud
as a victimless crime because corporations 
and civic institutions aren't people. But fraud harms real people
in virtually every case: the employees of Parmalat 
who lost their jobs, the citizens of Dixon whose taxes
subsidized horse breeding, the customers of companies
which raise their prices to offset losses. Sometimes the effects are obvious
and devestating, like when Bernie Madoff caused thousands
of people to lose their life savings. But often they're subtle
and not easy to untangle. Yet someone, 
somewhere is left holding the bill.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Parmalat falsified financial statements to hide losses from their subsidiaries.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 10, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model
MJ's free throw dunk. Say MJ starts, as one does,
at zero meters off the ground, and jumps with an initial vertical
velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is the acceleration due to gravity on Earth?
Options: A. -9.8 meters per second squared, B. -4.9 meters per second squared, C. -32 meters per second squared, D. -16 meters per second squared
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the approximate human limit for hang time on a flat surface? Options: A. 0.5 seconds, B. 1 second, C. 2 seconds, D. 5 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the gravitational acceleration on Earth? Options: A. 8.87 meters per second squared, B. 9.8 meters per second squared, C. 24.92 meters per second squared, D. 4.51 meters per second squared Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the equation that models hang time, as mentioned in the transcript? Options: A. Height = initial height + initial velocity * time + gravitational acceleration * time, B. Height = initial height + initial velocity * time + 0.5 * gravitational acceleration * time^2, C. Height = initial height + initial velocity * time - gravitational acceleration * time, D. Height = initial height + initial velocity * time - 0.5 * gravitational acceleration * time^2 Correct Option: B
Question 4: If Michael Jordan jumps with an initial vertical velocity of 4.51 meters per second, what is his maximum height off the ground, according to the parabola's vertex? Options: A. 0.5 meters, B. 1.038 meters, C. 2 meters, D. 4 meters Correct Option: B
Question 5: What does the difference between the X-intercepts of the parabola represent? Options: A. The time it takes for Michael Jordan to reach his maximum height, B. The hang time of Michael Jordan's dunk, C. The initial velocity of Michael Jordan's jump, D. The gravitational acceleration on Earth Correct Option: B
Question 6: If Michael Jordan were to jump on Venus with the same force as he did on Earth, what would be his approximate hang time? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. A little over 1 second, C. 2 seconds, D. 5 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 7: What would happen to Michael Jordan's hang time if he were to jump on Jupiter? Options: A. It would increase due to Jupiter's weaker gravitational pull, B. It would remain the same as on Earth, C. It would decrease due to Jupiter's stronger gravitational pull, D. It would become infinite Correct Option: C
Question 8: If Michael Jordan were to jump on the moon, what would be his approximate hang time? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. 1-2 seconds, C. 2-3 seconds, D. Over 5 seconds Correct Option: D
Question 9: How would the shape of the parabola change if the gravitational acceleration were to increase? Options: A. The parabola would become wider and shallower, B. The parabola would become narrower and deeper, C. The parabola would remain the same, D. The parabola would become a straight line Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be inferred about the relationship between gravitational acceleration and hang time? Options: A. As gravitational acceleration increases, hang time also increases, B. As gravitational acceleration decreases, hang time also decreases, C. As gravitational acceleration increases, hang time decreases, D. There is no relationship between gravitational acceleration and hang time Correct Option: C

**Transcript**:
Michael Jordan once said, "I don't know whether I'll fly or not. I know that when I'm in the air sometimes I feel like I don't ever
have to come down." But thanks to Isaac Newton, we know that what goes up
must eventually come down. In fact, the human limit 
on a flat surface for hang time, or the time from when your feet leave
the ground to when they touch down again, is only about one second, and, yes, that even includes his airness, whose infamous dunk 
from the free throw line has been calculated at .92 seconds. And, of course, gravity is what's making it
so hard to stay in the air longer. Earth's gravity pulls all nearby objects
towards the planet's surface, accelerating them 
at 9.8 meters per second squared. As soon as you jump,
gravity is already pulling you back down. Using what we know about gravity, we can derive a fairly simple equation
that models hang time. This equation states that the height
of a falling object above a surface is equal to the object's initial height
from the surface plus its initial velocity multiplied by how many seconds
it's been in the air, plus half of the 
gravitational acceleration multiplied by the square of the number
of seconds spent in the air. Now we can use this equation to model

velocity of 4.51 meters per second. Let's see what happens if we model
this equation on a coordinate grid. Since the formula is quadratic, the relationship between height
and time spent in the air has the shape of a parabola. So what does it tell us about MJ's dunk? Well, the parabola's vertex shows us
his maximum height off the ground at 1.038 meters, and the X-intercepts tell us 
when he took off and when he landed,
with the difference being the hang time. It looks like Earth's gravity
makes it pretty hard for even MJ to get some solid hang time. But what if he were playing an away game
somewhere else, somewhere far? Well, the gravitational acceleration
on our nearest planetary neighbor, Venus, is 8.87 meters per second squared, 
pretty similar to Earth's. If Michael jumped here with the same
force as he did back on Earth, he would be able to get more 
than a meter off the ground, giving him a hang time 
of a little over one second. The competition on Jupiter
with its gravitational pull of 24.92 meters per second squared
would be much less entertaining. Here, Michael wouldn't even
get a half meter off the ground, and would remain airborne
a mere .41 seconds. But a game on the moon
would be quite spectacular. MJ could take off from behind half court, jumping over six meters high, and his hang time of over 
five and half seconds, would be long enough for anyone
to believe he could fly.

Correct Option: C

Question 5: What does the difference between the X-intercepts of the parabola represent? Options: A. The time it takes for Michael Jordan to reach his maximum height, B. The hang time of Michael Jordan's dunk, C. The initial velocity of Michael Jordan's jump, D. The gravitational acceleration on Earth Correct Option: B
Question 6: If Michael Jordan were to jump on Venus with the same force as he did on Earth, what would be his approximate hang time? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. A little over 1 second, C. 2 seconds, D. 5 seconds Correct Option: B
Question 7: What would happen to Michael Jordan's hang time if he were to jump on Jupiter? Options: A. It would increase due to Jupiter's weaker gravitational pull, B. It would remain the same as on Earth, C. It would decrease due to Jupiter's stronger gravitational pull, D. It would become infinite Correct Option: C
Question 8: If Michael Jordan were to jump on the moon, what would be his approximate hang time? Options: A. Less than 1 second, B. 1-2 seconds, C. 2-3 seconds, D. Over 5 seconds Correct Option: D
Question 9: How would the shape of the parabola change if the gravitational acceleration were to increase? Options: A. The parabola would become wider and shallower, B. The parabola would become narrower and deeper, C. The parabola would remain the same, D. The parabola would become a straight line Correct Option: B
Question 10: What can be inferred about the relationship between gravitational acceleration and hang time? Options: A. As gravitational acceleration increases, hang time also increases, B. As gravitational acceleration decreases, hang time also decreases, C. As gravitational acceleration increases, hang time decreases, D. There is no relationship between gravitational acceleration and hang time Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that none of the generated MCQs exactly match the ground truth MCQ. However, based on the question intent, options, and content, I identified the most similar generated MCQ.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the moment in Michael Jordan's free-throw dunk represented by the equation 0=-4.9(0)^2+4.51(0). This equation corresponds to the moment when Michael Jordan takes off, which is the initial point of the dunk.

Among the generated MCQs, Question 5 is the most similar, as it asks about the interpretation of the parabola's X-intercepts, which represent the takeoff and landing points of Michael Jordan's dunk. Although the question is not an exact match, it is related to the concept of identifying specific moments in the dunk based on the equation or parabola.

However, a closer examination of the generated MCQs reveals that none of them directly ask about the equation 0=-4.9(0)^2+4.51(0) or the specific moment it represents. Therefore, I must conclude that there is no generated MCQ that closely matches the ground truth MCQ.

If I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the available options, I would select Question 5, but with the understanding that it is not a close match.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 5

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Gluten can be found in which type of grains?
Options: A. Wheat, B. Rye, C. Barley, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten primarily composed of? Options: A. Gliadin and starch, B. Glutenin and carbohydrates, C. Gliadin and glutenin, D. Wheat and rye Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which grains commonly contain gluten? Options: A. Rice, corn, and oats, B. Wheat, rye, and barley, C. Quinoa, amaranth, and teff, D. Buckwheat, millet, and sorghum Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of gluten in food products? Options: A. To add flavor and texture, B. To preserve food and extend shelf life, C. To provide the elastic consistency of dough and chewiness of foods, D. To enhance nutritional value Correct Option: C
Question 4: A person with a wheat allergy may experience which of the following reactions? Options: A. Mild problems, such as hives and itching, B. A potentially life-threatening reaction called anaphylaxis, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. Medication to manage symptoms, B. A gluten-free diet, C. Surgery to repair intestinal damage, D. A combination of medication and surgery Correct Option: B
Question 6: A person with non-celiac gluten sensitivity may experience which of the following symptoms? Options: A. Painful gut symptoms, fatigue, brain fog, joint pain, or skin rash, B. Anaphylaxis, osteoporosis, and infertility, C. Celiac disease and wheat allergy, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why is it challenging to diagnose non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. There is no reliable blood or tissue test, B. The symptoms are identical to celiac disease and wheat allergy, C. The condition is extremely rare, D. All of the above Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the nocebo effect, and how might it relate to gluten sensitivity? Options: A. The nocebo effect is a positive response to a treatment, and it may play a role in alleviating gluten sensitivity symptoms, B. The nocebo effect is a negative response to a treatment, and it may play a role in exacerbating gluten sensitivity symptoms, C. The nocebo effect is a neutral response to a treatment, and it has no relation to gluten sensitivity, D. The nocebo effect is a psychological phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and it may contribute to perceived gluten sensitivity Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is an alternative name that might be more accurate for non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Gluten allergy, C. Celiac disease, D. Irritable bowel syndrome Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, approximately how many people in the U.S. have celiac disease? Options: A. 1 in 10, B. 1 in 100 to 200, C. 1 in 1,000, D. 1 in 10,000 Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 2. 

This question has the same intent as the ground truth MCQ, which is to identify the types of grains that commonly contain gluten. The options in Question 2 are also similar to the ground truth MCQ, with the correct option (B. Wheat, rye, and barley) matching the correct option in the ground truth MCQ (D. All of the above, which refers to wheat, rye, and barley). 

Therefore, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is 2.

they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

that your friend, being a reasonable individual

Anaphylaxis, osteoporosis, and infertility, C. Celiac disease and wheat allergy, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why is it challenging to diagnose non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. There is no reliable blood or tissue test, B. The symptoms are identical to celiac disease and wheat allergy, C. The condition is extremely rare, D. All of the above Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the nocebo effect, and how might it relate to gluten sensitivity? Options: A. The nocebo effect is a positive response to a treatment, and it may play a role in alleviating gluten sensitivity symptoms, B. The nocebo effect is a negative response to a treatment, and it may play a role in exacerbating gluten sensitivity symptoms, C. The nocebo effect is a neutral response to a treatment, and it has no relation to gluten sensitivity, D. The nocebo effect is a psychological phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and it may contribute to perceived gluten sensitivity Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is an alternative name that might be more accurate for non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Gluten allergy, C. Celiac disease, D. Irritable bowel syndrome Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, approximately how many people in the U.S. have celiac disease? Options: A. 1 in 10, B. 1 in 100 to 200, C. 1 in 1,000, D. 1 in 10,000 Correct Option: B

Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is not explicitly present in the provided set. However, based on the content and intent, I can identify a generated MCQ that partially matches the ground truth MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 12, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Maybe you've recently seen the phrase
"gluten-free" on food packaging, or take-out menus, shampoo bottles,
apartment listings, the tag of your shirt, on a hammer, as a lower back tattoo,
or in your friend's resume. Next time someone starts telling you
about their newfound freedom from gluten, here are some questions you can ask, and the well-informed answers
that your friend, being a reasonable individual
making educated dietary choices, and by no means just following 
the latest diet craze, will tell you. What is gluten? Gluten is an insoluble protein composite made up of two proteins 
named gliadin and glutenin. Where might you encounter gluten? Gluten is found in certain grains,
particularly wheat, rye and barley. What has gluten been doing for
the previous entirety of human history, and why do you suddenly care about it? Gluten is responsible 
for the elastic consistency of dough and the chewiness of foods 
made from wheat flour, like bread and pasta. For some people, 
these foods cause problems, namely wheat allergy, celiac disease,
and non-celiac gluten sensitivity. Wheat allergy is an uncommon condition that occurs when a person's immune system mounts an allergic response 
to wheat proteins, leading to mild problems,
and in rare cases, a potential dangerous reaction
called anaphylaxis. Celiac disease is an inherited disease, in which eating foods with gluten leads to inflammation and damage
of the lining of the small intestine. This impairs intestinal function, leading to problems like belly pain,
bloating, gas, diarrhea, weight loss, skin rash, bone problems
like osteoporosis, iron deficiency, small stature, 
infertility, fatigue and depression. Untreated, celiac disease 
increases the risk of developing certain types of cancer. Celiac disease is present in one 
in every 100 to 200 persons in the U.S. When blood tests suggest 
the possibility of celiac, the diagnosis is confirmed with a biopsy. The most effective treatment
is a gluten-free diet, which helps heal intestinal damage
and improve symptoms. Some people don't have celiac disease
or a wheat allergy, but still experience symptoms
when they eat foods with gluten. These people have non-celiac
gluten sensitivity. They experience painful gut symptoms and suffer from fatigue, brain fog,
joint pain or skin rash. A gluten-free diet typically helps
with these symptoms. So how many people actually
have this gluten sensitivity you speak of? Gluten sensitivity's occurrence 
in the general population is unclear, but likely much more common
than wheat allergy or celiac disease. Diagnosis is based 
on the development of symptoms, the absence of wheat allergy
and celiac disease, and subsequent improvement
on a gluten-free diet. There's no reliable blood or tissue test, partly because gluten sensitivity
isn't a single disease, and has a number 
of different possible causes. For example, it may be the case that gluten can activate the immune system
in the small intestine, or cause it to become leaky. But sometimes, people claiming
gluten sensitivity are actually sensitive 
not to wheat proteins, but sugars found in wheat and other foods,
called fructans. The human intestine can't break down
or absorb fructans, so they make their way 
to the large intestine or colon, where they're fermented by bacteria, producing short-chain fatty acids
and gases. This leads to unpleasant symptoms
in some people with bowel problems. Another possible explanation behind
gluten sensitivity is the nocebo effect. This occurs when a person believes
something will cause problems, and because of that belief, it does. It's the opposite of the more well-known
and much more fortuitous placebo effect. Given how much bad press 
gluten is getting in the media, the nocebo response may play a role for some people who think
they're sensitive to gluten. For all these reasons, it's clear that 
the problems people develop when they eat wheat and other grains
aren't exclusively due to gluten. So a better name than
non-celiac gluten sensitivty might be wheat intolerance.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: When a person believes something will cause problems and because of that belief, it does, it is called:
Options: A. Bad press, B. A placebo effect, C. Sensitivity, D. Nocebo effect
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is gluten primarily composed of? Options: A. Gliadin and starch, B. Glutenin and carbohydrates, C. Gliadin and glutenin, D. Wheat and rye Correct Option: C
Question 2: Which grains commonly contain gluten? Options: A. Rice, corn, and oats, B. Wheat, rye, and barley, C. Quinoa, amaranth, and teff, D. Buckwheat, millet, and sorghum Correct Option: B
Question 3: What is the primary function of gluten in food products? Options: A. To add flavor and texture, B. To preserve food and extend shelf life, C. To provide the elastic consistency of dough and chewiness of foods, D. To enhance nutritional value Correct Option: C
Question 4: A person with a wheat allergy may experience which of the following reactions? Options: A. Mild problems, such as hives and itching, B. A potentially life-threatening reaction called anaphylaxis, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: C
Question 5: What is the most effective treatment for celiac disease? Options: A. Medication to manage symptoms, B. A gluten-free diet, C. Surgery to repair intestinal damage, D. A combination of medication and surgery Correct Option: B
Question 6: A person with non-celiac gluten sensitivity may experience which of the following symptoms? Options: A. Painful gut symptoms, fatigue, brain fog, joint pain, or skin rash, B. Anaphylaxis, osteoporosis, and infertility, C. Celiac disease and wheat allergy, D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 7: Why is it challenging to diagnose non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. There is no reliable blood or tissue test, B. The symptoms are identical to celiac disease and wheat allergy, C. The condition is extremely rare, D. All of the above Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the nocebo effect, and how might it relate to gluten sensitivity? Options: A. The nocebo effect is a positive response to a treatment, and it may play a role in alleviating gluten sensitivity symptoms, B. The nocebo effect is a negative response to a treatment, and it may play a role in exacerbating gluten sensitivity symptoms, C. The nocebo effect is a neutral response to a treatment, and it has no relation to gluten sensitivity, D. The nocebo effect is a psychological phenomenon where a person believes something will cause problems, and it may contribute to perceived gluten sensitivity Correct Option: D
Question 9: What is an alternative name that might be more accurate for non-celiac gluten sensitivity? Options: A. Wheat intolerance, B. Gluten allergy, C. Celiac disease, D. Irritable bowel syndrome Correct Option: A
Question 10: According to the transcript, approximately how many people in the U.S. have celiac disease? Options: A. 1 in 10, B. 1 in 100 to 200, C. 1 in 1,000, D. 1 in 10,000 Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 13, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[MUSIC PLAYING] Getting sick
stinks-- literally. What I mean is that
different diseases give off different odors, and sometimes
doctors can diagnose you based on how you smell. I'm Anna Rothschild, and
this is "Gross Science." So it turns out
that doctors have known since the
time of Hippocrates that different diseases
smell different ways. For example,
typhoid-- which causes fever, abdominal pain,
delirium, and can kill you-- smells like freshly
baked brown bread. Other infections smell
totally differently. The skin of people with
the virus yellow fever is said to smell
like a butcher shop. And if you have a burn wound
infected with the bacteria Pseudomonas, it might
smell like grape juice. But infections from
bacteria and viruses aren't the only
diseases that can make you emit a certain aroma. Genetic conditions--
ones you're born with-- can do the same thing. For example, maple
syrup urine disease, which can be fatal
if untreated, makes you smell like maple syrup. And then there's a condition
called Trimethylaminuria, which has absolutely no
symptoms, except that it makes you smell like rotten fish. And those are just diseases
that humans can smell. Dogs can actually sniff out
certain types of cancer, and scientists have now
created electronic noses. These are smelling
machines that can detect very faint
traces of compounds that the human nose would
never be able to pick up. Beep boop beep. In fact, researchers are looking
into using dogs or e-noses to detect diseases before
they become dangerous. So while sniffing out
the source of an illness has never really
gone away, there's a whole new frontier of
stench science out there. Just take a whiff. Ew. What's the grossest thing
you've ever smelled? Let me know in the comments. And for more "Gross Science"
and weird facts, hit Subscribe.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: True or False: Diseases from bacteria and viruses are the only diseases that give off smells.
Options: A. True, B. False
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the name of the host of the "Gross Science" show? Options: A. Anna Rothschild, B. Hippocrates, C. Pseudomonas, D. Trimethylaminuria Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is the characteristic smell associated with typhoid? Options: A. Freshly baked brown bread, B. Rotten fish, C. Maple syrup, D. Grape juice Correct Option: A
Question 3: A patient comes to the doctor with symptoms of fever and abdominal pain. The doctor notices a distinct smell of freshly baked brown bread. What disease might the doctor suspect? Options: A. Yellow fever, B. Typhoid, C. Maple syrup urine disease, D. Trimethylaminuria Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the main difference between the way humans and dogs detect diseases through smell? Options: A. Humans can detect fainter traces of compounds, B. Dogs can detect a wider range of diseases, C. Humans rely on electronic noses, while dogs use their natural sense of smell, D. Dogs can detect very faint traces of compounds that humans cannot Correct Option: D
Question 5: What is the name of the genetic condition that makes a person smell like rotten fish? Options: A. Maple syrup urine disease, B. Trimethylaminuria, C. Typhoid, D. Yellow fever Correct Option: B
Question 6: How do scientists hope to use dogs or electronic noses in the future? Options: A. To detect diseases after they become dangerous, B. To detect diseases before they become dangerous, C. To diagnose diseases based on symptoms, D. To treat diseases with antibiotics Correct Option: B
Question 7: What is the purpose of electronic noses in the field of medicine? Options: A. To detect very faint traces of compounds that the human nose cannot, B. To diagnose diseases based on symptoms, C. To treat diseases with antibiotics, D. To detect a wide range of diseases Correct Option: A
Question 8: Compare and contrast the smells associated with different diseases. What can be inferred about the relationship between diseases and their characteristic smells? Options: A. Each disease has a unique smell that is unrelated to other diseases, B. Diseases caused by bacteria have similar smells, while diseases caused by viruses have distinct smells, C. Diseases can be grouped into categories based on their characteristic smells, D. The smell of a disease is not related to its cause or symptoms Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the potential benefit of using dogs or electronic noses to detect diseases? Options: A. It could lead to more accurate diagnoses, B. It could lead to earlier detection and treatment of diseases, C. It could reduce the need for medical testing, D. It could increase the reliance on antibiotics Correct Option: B
Question 10: Evaluate the effectiveness of using smell as a diagnostic tool in medicine. What are the potential advantages and limitations of this approach? Options: A. Smell is a reliable and accurate diagnostic tool with no limitations, B. Smell can be a useful diagnostic tool, but it has limitations and should be used in conjunction with other methods, C. Smell is not a useful diagnostic tool and should not be used in medicine, D. Smell can only be used to diagnose diseases caused by bacteria Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

But since Question 8 does not directly answer the ground truth MCQ and is an open-ended question, it is not a perfect match.

Upon closer inspection, it appears that none of the provided generated MCQs directly match the ground truth MCQ.

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. **Transcript**:
[MUSIC PLAYING] Getting sick
stinks-- literally. What I mean is that
different diseases give off different odors, and sometimes
doctors can diagnose you based on how you smell. I'm Anna Rothschild, and
this is "Gross Science." So it turns out
that doctors have known since the
time of Hippocrates that different diseases
smell different ways. For example,
typhoid-- which causes fever, abdominal pain,
delirium, and can kill you-- smells like freshly
baked brown bread. Other infections smell
totally differently. The skin of people with
the virus yellow fever is said to smell
like a butcher shop. And if you have a burn wound
infected with the bacteria Pseudomonas, it might
smell like grape juice. But infections from
bacteria and viruses aren't the only
diseases that can make you emit a certain aroma. Genetic conditions--
ones you're born with-- can do the same thing. For example, maple
syrup urine disease, which can be fatal
if untreated, makes you smell like maple syrup. And then there's a condition
called Trimethylaminuria, which has absolutely no
symptoms, except that it makes you smell like rotten fish. And those are just diseases
that humans can smell. Dogs can actually sniff out
certain types of cancer, and scientists have now
created electronic noses. These are smelling
machines that can detect very faint
traces of compounds that the human nose would
never be able to pick up. Beep boop beep. In fact, researchers are looking
into using dogs or e-noses to detect diseases before
they become dangerous. So while sniffing out
the source of an illness has never really
gone away, there's a whole new frontier of
stench science out there. Just take a whiff. Ew. What's the grossest thing
you've ever smelled? Let me know in the comments. And for more "Gross Science"
and weird facts, hit Subscribe.
